_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Central Grocers, Inc. uses a direct ammonia refrigeration system for cooling Holding Freezer, Ice Cream Freezer, Coolers, Banana Rooms, and Dock.  The refrigeration system uses ammonia refrigerant in a two stage evaporation/condensation cycle.



The ammonia related equipment could be divided into four sections.  

1.    The "ultra low pressure" equipment contains (2) Ice Cream Freezer Evaporators, (1) Ultra Low Temp Pump Package (ULTPR), (1) Oil Pot and (1) Ultra Low Temp Booster Compressor.

2.    The "low pressure" equipment contains (6) Freezer Evaporators, (1) Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR), (1) Oil Pot (1) and (3) Low Temp Booster Compressors.    

3.    The "intermediate pressure" equipment contains (4) Meat Cooler Evaporators, (4) Dairy/Deli Evaporators, (2) 55deg Dry Produce Evaporators, (2) 55/34deg Dry Produce Evaporators, (2) 34deg Wet Produce Evaporators, (2) 45deg Dry Produce Evaporators, (14) 35deg Dock Evaporators, (10) Banana Room Evaporators, (1) High Temp Pump Package (HTPR), (1) Oil Pot, (3) High Stage Compressors, and (1) Swing Compressor.

4.    The "high-pressure" equipment includes the (2) Evaporative Condensers and (1) Thermo-Siphon/High Pressure Receiver (TSHPR) and associated piping/valves.



Ammonia refrigeration provides cooling by utilizing the heat input required to change a liquid to a vapor (latent heat of evaporation) and then heat output discharged when a gas collapses to form liquid (latent heat of condensation). 'Heat' is quantified by definition and is 'labeled' as calories or Btu (British Thermal Unit).  One Btu, by definition, equals the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of one pound of water, 1 ?F when the water is 70 ?F, and at sea level pressure.  All other compounds reference this definition.  For example, the amount of heat required to raise the temperature of liquid ammonia at 70 ?F and 128.8 psia  = 1.129 Btu/lb (this is also referred to as the "Specific Heat"). The amount of heat required to vaporize 1 pound of ammon

ia (at a corresponding pressure to 70 ?F, 128.8 psia) = 508.6 Btu.  Therefore, a system is 500 times more efficient in heat transfer per pound of ammonia utilized if the system incorporates change of state: liquid boiling off forming a vapor.



This 'heat' must be removed from the system or the system would reach a point that no more 'heat' could be absorbed (e.g. the liquid evaporates, and now must be condensed).  This is accomplished by compressing the gas to a pressure such that Air/Water passing over the Condenser coils would accept heat from the gas.  The (vaporized) gas, in rejecting heat, condenses, and thus provides liquid to begin the cycle again.



The ammonia flow direction is based on pressure differences (either by gravity or forced) and by the difference in volume between a gas and a liquid containing the same amount of ammonia.  The active driver of this system is the compressor.



The evaporation/condensation cycle is as follows:



Ultra Low Pressure Suction

    Ammonia liquid is pumped from the Ultra Low Temp Pump Package (ULTPR) to the ultra low-temp evaporators where heat is absorbed from the rooms.  The liquid ammonia boils absorbing the room heat and is converted from a liquid to a vapor.  Not all of the liquid boils off.  The mixture of liquid and vapor then returns to the Ultra Low Temp Pump Package (ULTPR) where the liquid and vapor are separated so that the liquid can be circulated back to the evaporators.



    The low-pressure vapor passes through the Ultra Low Temp Pump Package (ULTPR) and enters the Booster Compressor suction line.  In the Ultra Low Temp Booster Compressor, the vapor is compressed to a higher pressure.  In this case it is compressed to 31.4 PSIG.  The ammonia is co-mingled with lubricating oil in the compressor.



    The ammonia vapor is directed to the oil separator to remove the majority of oil (employed to lubricate and cool the compressor) before being discharged to the Intercooler/High Temp Pump Package (HTPR) and th

en to the High Stage Compressors.



    Liquid from the High Temp Pump Package (HTPR) is then fed to the Ultra Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR) to replace the liquid that was boiled out of the ultra low temperature system.



Low Pressure Suction

    Ammonia liquid is pumped from the Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR) to the low-temp evaporators where heat is absorbed from the rooms.  The liquid ammonia boils absorbing the room heat and is converted from a liquid to a vapor.  Not all of the liquid boils off.  The mixture of liquid and vapor then returns to the Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR) where the liquid and vapor are separated so that the liquid can be circulated back to the evaporators.



    The low-pressure vapor passes through the Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR) and enters the Low Temp Compressor suction line.  In the Low Temp Booster Compressors, the vapor is compressed to superheated, higher pressure.  The ammonia is co-mingled with lubricating oil in the compressor.



    The ammonia vapor is directed to the oil separator to remove the majority of oil (employed to lubricate and cool the compressor) before being discharged to the Intercooler/High Temp Pump Package (HTPR) and then to the High Stage Compressors.



    Liquid from the High Temp Pump Package (HTPR) is then fed to the Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR) to replace the liquid that was boiled out of the low temperature system.





Intermediate Suction

    Ammonia liquid is pumped from the High Temp Pump Package (HTPR) to the intermediate-temp evaporators where heat is absorbed from the rooms.  The liquid ammonia boils absorbing the room heat and is converted from a liquid to a vapor.  Not all of the liquid boils off.  The mixture of liquid and vapor then returns to the High Temp Pump Package (HTPR) where the liquid and vapor are separated so that the liquid can be circulated back to the evaporators.



    The ammonia vapor from the high temp loads and booster compressors, at intermediate pressure, pass through the High Temp Pump P

ackage (HTPR) and enters the High Stage Compressor suction line.  In the High Stage Compressor, the vapor is compressed to superheated, higher pressure.  The ammonia is co-mingled with lubricating oil in the compressor.



    The ammonia vapor is directed to the oil separator to remove the majority of oil (employed to lubricate and cool the compressor) before being discharged to the evaporative condensers as superheated, high-pressure vapor.



Condensing

    The high-pressure vapor passes to the evaporative condensers where the heat is rejected from the gaseous ammonia to the atmosphere and the ammonia is condensed into liquid. The fans and water pumps automatically start (sequentially) to maintain the ammonia high-pressure set point.



    The condensed liquid ammonia is collected in the High Pressure Receiver (HPR) and then is fed into the High Temp Pump Package (HTPR).  The Low Temp Pump Package (LTPR) is then fed liquid from the High Temp Pump Receiver (HTPR).



Secondary Ammonia Cycles

    High Pressure Liquid (HPL) ammonia is directed from the Thermo-Siphon/High Pressure Receiver (TSHPR) to the oil coolers of the compressors, where it absorbs heat from the compressor oil. The Liquid Ammonia Boils and Ammonia Vapor and Liquid return to the Thermo-Siphon/High Pressure Receiver. Vapor from Thermo-Siphon oil cooling goes from the Thermo-Siphon/High Pressure Receiver (TSHPR) to the Evaporative condensers where the heat is rejected from the gaseous ammonia to the atmosphere and the ammonia is condensed into liquid.
